Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to log my break at work. It was Jamie, my best friend, and her voice trembled as she asked if I had a moment. She’d just had a huge fight with her partner, and I could hear the tears she was trying to hold back. My heart twisted—I knew she needed me to listen, to be there for her, like I always promised I would be. But I was staring at the break timer on my screen, knowing management was watching every second. The phone queue was packed, and if I went over my allotted time, I’d get another warning. I could almost hear my supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding me that every minute counted. Jamie’s words blurred with the ticking of the clock, and I felt torn in two—one part desperate to comfort my friend, the other weighed down by the pressure to keep my job. I gripped the phone tighter, caught between the expectations of being a good friend and a reliable employee, not sure which role I could afford to let down.
